question_stem:
Suppose that the data in liverpool_2223_season.csv has been read into R as a dataframe liverpool.

Explain what the following code does:

liverpool 

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-1


Comment if the above code is an improvement or not, over:

barplot(table(liverpool$GF))

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-2
question_stem_html:
Suppose that the data in liverpool_2223_season.csv has been read into R as a dataframe liverpool.

  • Explain what the following code does:
liverpool <- read.csv("liverpool_2223_season.csv")
range_gf <- range(liverpool$GF)
gf_vals <- range_gf[1]:range_gf[2]
gf_tbl <- rep(0, length=length(gf_vals))
names(gf_tbl) <- gf_vals

tmp_table <- table(liverpool$GF)
gf_tbl[names(tmp_table)] <- tmp_table

barplot(gf_tbl)

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-1

  • Comment if the above code is an improvement or not, over:
barplot(table(liverpool$GF))

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-2

items.part_stem_html:
Suppose that the data in liverpool_2223_season.csv has been read into R as a dataframe liverpool.

  • Explain what the following code does:
liverpool <- read.csv("liverpool_2223_season.csv")
range_gf <- range(liverpool$GF)
gf_vals <- range_gf[1]:range_gf[2]
gf_tbl <- rep(0, length=length(gf_vals))
names(gf_tbl) <- gf_vals

tmp_table <- table(liverpool$GF)
gf_tbl[names(tmp_table)] <- tmp_table

barplot(gf_tbl)

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-1

  • Comment if the above code is an improvement or not, over:
barplot(table(liverpool$GF))

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-2
items.solution:
Explanation of code:

# returns a vector of length 2, consisting of the max and min of the number of 
# goals scored by liverpool in a game.
range_gf 

The benefit of the above code is that it also depicts the zero counts. Using the other piece of code would give a false view of the data to a viewer.

# goals scored by liverpool in a game.
range_gf 

The benefit of the above code is that it also depicts the zero counts. Using the other piece of code would give a false view of the data to a viewer.



Explanation of code:

# returns a vector of length 2, consisting of the max and min of the number of 
# goals scored by liverpool in a game.
range_gf 

The benefit of the above code is that it also depicts the zero counts.
Using the other piece of code would give a false view of the data to
a viewer.
items.solution_html:
• Explanation of code:
# returns a vector of length 2, consisting of the max and min of the number of 
# goals scored by liverpool in a game.
range_gf <- range(liverpool$GF)

# creates a placeholder vector for the number of times a number of goals was 
# scored in a a game.
gf_vals <- range_gf[1]:range_gf[2]
gf_tbl <- rep(0, length=length(gf_vals))
# adds names to the placeholder vector
names(gf_tbl) <- gf_vals

# Tabulates the number of times a particular number of goals was scored.
tmp_table <- table(liverpool$GF)
# Fills up the placeholder with the number of goals scored. Unmodified 
# values are left as 0
gf_tbl[names(tmp_table)] <- tmp_table

barplot(gf_tbl)
  • The benefit of the above code is that it also depicts the zero counts. Using the other piece of code would give a false view of the data to a viewer.

  • The benefit of the above code is that it also depicts the zero counts. Using the other piece of code would give a false view of the data to a viewer.
